speaker: Neil
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

speaker: Georgina
text: And I’m Georgina.

speaker: Neil
text: Can you swim, Georgina?

speaker: Georgina
text: I can, Neil. I learned to swim as a child and now I enjoy swimming for exercise and to relax.

speaker: take a dip
text: In the summer hundreds of keen swimmers, like Georgina, head off to swimming pools, lakes and beaches to take a dip – an informal idiom meaning ‘go for a swim’.

speaker: Georgina
text: Swimming has many health benefits and since ancient times has been used to promote strength and wellbeing.

speaker: Neil
text: But swimming’s not just about exercise – there’s far more to it beneath the surface as we’ll be finding out in this programme on the history of swimming.

speaker: swum against the tide
text: Although evidence suggests that ancient Mediterranean people dived eagerly into temple pleasure pools, lakes and the sea, other cultures have swum against the tide – another swimming idiom there, Neil - meaning ‘not to follow what everyone else is doing’.

speaker: Neil
text: Someone who did enjoy swimming was the poet, Lord Byron. He wrote poems popularising the sport and in 1810 swam the Hellespont, a stretch of water separating Europe from Asia. But in which modern country can the Hellespont be found - that’s my quiz question, Georgina. Is it:

speaker: Neil
text: a) Greece?

speaker: Neil
text: b) Cyprus?, or

speaker: Neil
text: c) Turkey?

speaker: Georgina
text: I think Lord Byron visited Istanbul, so I’ll say c) Turkey.

speaker: Neil
text: OK, we’ll find out the answer at the end of the programme. For all its good points, swimming seems to have lost its appeal in Europe after the decline of the Roman Empire.

speaker: Georgina
text: According to historian and swimming enthusiast, Professor Kevin Dawson, the rise of Christian beliefs discouraged swimming, as he explains here to BBC World Service programme, The Forum:

speaker: immodestnude immodest
text: You have some beliefs that water is this unsafe space, unnatural space for human beings… it’s a perpetuation of the chaos that existed before God created land, or that water is a mechanism for punishment like the Great Flood story or pharaoh’s army being destroyed in the Red Sea… but then there’s also beliefs that swimming is immodest… most people at the time swam nude and so church officials discouraged swimming because they felt that it lead to immodest behaviour.

speaker: immodest
text: As well as being considered unsafe or chaotic, swimming was seen as immodest – shocking because it shows too much of the body.

speaker: nude
text: This was because most people at the time swam nude – naked, without clothes.

speaker: Neil
text: Another place with a long history of swimming is the remote Maldives Islands in the Indian Ocean.

speaker: Georgina
text: In the Maldives, access to shallow, warm sea-water lakes called lagoons makes it an unbeatable place for swimming.

speaker: Neil
text: But even on a tropical island, things haven’t always gone swimmingly as diver and Maldives resident, Mikael Rosen, told BBC World Service programme, The Forum:

speaker: Georgina
text: Listen for the reason Mikael gives for the change in people’s attitudes to swimming in the Maldives:

speaker: playing hooky got frowned upon,
text: Most citizens of the Maldives have half a mile to a lukewarm lagoon. Given that, they could be world leaders in swimming, but in the 1960s the government recruited a lot of teachers from India, Sri Lanka. They didn’t know anything about the water culture and they noticed that the young students playing hooky – they were in the lagoons, and swimming soon got frowned upon, but now the government and the local organisations – they try to reclaim swimming.

speaker: Georgina
text: Did you hear the reason Mikael gave, Neil?

speaker: playing hookyPlay hooky
text: Yes, he said that young students were playing hooky to go swimming in the lagoons. Play hooky is an informal way of saying ‘stay away from school without permission’.

speaker: frowned upon
text: Right, and that meant swimming quickly got frowned upon, or disapproved of.

speaker: Neil
text: It seems a bit unfair since there was already a strong culture of swimming in the Maldives which the arriving teachers didn’t fully appreciate.

speaker: Georgina
text: Well, I know which I’d rather do – sit in a classroom or swim in a warm tropical lagoon!

speaker: Neil
text: Swimming, right? But then you would never have learned about Lord Byron…

speaker: Georgina
text: Yes, in your quiz question you asked me about Lord Byron swimming the Hellespont, a stretch of water separating Europe from Asia.

speaker: Neil
text: I asked you in which country the Hellespont can be found. Is it: a) Greece? b) Cyprus? or c) Turkey? What did you say?

speaker: Georgina
text: I said c) Turkey. Was I right?

speaker: Neil
text: Yes, you were, Georgina! The Hellespont, also known as the Straits of Dardanelles, is a six-kilometre-wide stretch of water in Turkey.

speaker: taking a dip.
text: Let’s recap the vocabulary from this programme on swimming, which some people informally call taking a dip.

speaker: swims against the tide
text: Someone who swims against the tide refuses to do what everyone else is doing.

speaker: immodest -
text: In the past, swimming was considered immodest - shocking because it showed too much of the body.

speaker: nude.
text: Another word for naked or not wearing any clothes is nude.

speaker: play hooky
text: Children who play hooky stay away from school without permission.

speaker: frowned upon'
text: And finally, if something is 'frowned upon' it’s disapproved of.

speaker: Georgina
text: That’s all for our dive into the deep end of the vocabulary of swimming. As we’ve discovered, there’s plenty of idioms and expressions relating to swimming and water!
